comments.text: Not security sensitive. Misusing the security sensitive flag only restricts the number of people who can see your bug. Please don't use it when your issue is not security related.

comments.creator: antoine.mechelynck@gmail.com
comments.author: antoine.mechelynck@gmail.com
comments.raw_text:
(In reply to tmieske7 from comment #0)
> User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:8.0) Gecko/20111107 Firefox/8.0
> SeaMonkey/2.5
> Build ID: 20111107131154
> 
> Steps to reproduce:
> 
> edit file in composer
> 
> 
> Actual results:
> 
> my HEX codes get changed to RGB()
> 
> 
> 
> Expected results:
> 
> I DON'T want the above to change!!!

Use a plaintext editor instead?

By using a fancy HTML composer, you are limiting the output to what the composer will produce. Since the following are equivalent:
  color="white"               (a keyword)
  color="#FFFFFF"             (6 hex digits)
  color="#FFF"                (3 hex digit)
  color="rgb(255, 255, 255)"  (decimal RGB)
  color="rgb(100%,100%,100%)" (percent RGB)
and maybe others, Composer doesn't need to be able to produce more than one of them.

Setting Severity to enhancement in the hope of avoiding a fast WONTFIX.

comments.creator: neil@httl.net
comments.author: neil@httl.net
comments.text: My understanding is that this is due to the way the CSS serialiser works, so I'm redirecting this to Core:Style.
comments.raw_text: My understanding is that this is due to the way the CSS serialiser works, so I'm redirecting this to Core:Style.

comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text:
The CSS serialization spec is going to require the rgb() behavior for color serialization, I believe.

That said, why is that code even being hit?  What's the testcase here?
comments.raw_text:
The CSS serialization spec is going to require the rgb() behavior for color serialization, I believe.

That said, why is that code even being hit?  What's the testcase here?

comments.author: neil@httl.net
comments.creator: neil@httl.net
comments.raw_text: Actually, this might have been at least ameliorated on trunk, since we don't serialise style attributes any more, but using older builds, any inline style you specify via the style attribute will have its colours reset to rgb().
comments.text: Actually, this might have been at least ameliorated on trunk, since we don't serialise style attributes any more, but using older builds, any inline style you specify via the style attribute will have its colours reset to rgb().
